title: 115_hr210
content: The "Native American Energy Act" is cited as the short title. Appraisal reforms are introduced in Title XXVI of the Energy Policy Act of 1992. The "Native American Energy Act" allows Indian tribes to conduct their own appraisals for transactions involving their land or trust assets, with approval from the Secretary. The Secretary must review and approve or disapprove the appraisal within 30 days. The "Native American Energy Act" allows Indian tribes to conduct their own land or trust asset appraisals. If the Secretary fails to approve or disapprove an appraisal within 60 days, it is deemed approved. Indian tribes can waive the appraisal requirements by providing a written resolution approved by their governing body, including an express waiver of any claims for damages. The "Native American Energy Act" allows Indian tribes to waive appraisal requirements by providing a written resolution with an express waiver of any claims for damages against the United States. The Secretary must develop regulations for implementing this section, including approval standards for appraisals. The "Native American Energy Act" mandates appraisal reforms for oil and gas activities on Indian lands, including standardization of reference numbers and tracking systems for wells. Additionally, environmental reviews of major federal actions on Indian lands are required. Section 102 of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 is amended to include a provision for the review and comment of major Federal actions on Indian lands by Indian tribes and individuals residing in the affected area. The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 is amended to include a provision for the review of major Federal actions on Indian lands by Indian tribes and individuals in the affected area. The Chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality will develop regulations for implementation, including defining affected areas and consulting with Indian tribes. Definitions for 'Indian land' and 'Indian tribe' are based on the Energy Policy Act of 1992. The Native American Energy Act clarifies that the Secretary does not have additional authority over energy projects on Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act lands, except for section 6 of the Act. SEC. 5. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Judicial review for energy related actions must be filed within 60 days of final agency action, to be heard in the US District Court for the District of Columbia within 180 days. Appeals can be made to the US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The court must resolve appeals in energy-related actions within 180 days. No payments can be made for legal fees under certain sections, and if the plaintiff does not prevail, the defendant may be awarded fees and expenses. The court must resolve appeals in energy-related actions within 180 days. Legal fees may not be awarded unless the plaintiff's position was substantially justified or special circumstances exist. Definitions for "agency action" and "Indian land" are provided. The term "energy related action" refers to a cause of action seeking judicial review of a final agency action allowing activities on Indian Land related to oil, gas, coal, and other energy resources. The term "energy related action" encompasses activities on Indian Land related to oil, gas, coal, shale gas, oil shale, geothermal resources, wind or solar resources, underground coal gasification, biomass, or electricity generation, involving Indian Tribes or organizations with at least one Indian tribe. "Ultimately prevail" means the court rules in a final enforceable judgment. The term "ultimately prevail" refers to the court ruling in the party's favor on at least one cause of action underlying the requested relief, excluding instances where agency actions are modified without a court order. SEC. 6. TRIBAL BIOMASS DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. The Tribal Forest Protection Act of 2004 is amended to include a new section called "TRIBAL BIOMASS DEMONSTRATION PROJECT." For fiscal years 2016 through 2020, the Secretary will establish stewardship contracts with Indian tribes for biomass energy projects on Indian forest land and nearby communities. At least 4 new demonstration projects meeting specific criteria will be carried out each year. Eligibility criteria for tribes to participate will apply. Indian tribes must submit an application to the Secretary for a demonstration project on their forest land or rangeland. The Secretary will evaluate applications based on specific criteria, including increasing energy availability, enhancing economic development, and following guidelines from Public Law 108-278. The Secretary will evaluate applications from Indian tribes for demonstration projects on forest land or rangeland based on criteria such as economic development, improving power transmission, forest health, watershed enhancement, and promoting woody biomass use. The Secretary will make the criteria publicly available within 120 days of enactment and consult with stakeholders as much as possible during implementation. The Secretary will consult with Indian tribes and intertribal organizations, receive tribal applications, and enter into contracts and agreements under this section. A report describing the applications and agreements must be submitted to Congress within one year. Upon request, the Secretary will incorporate management plans into contracts or agreements with Indian tribes. Stewardship contracts on Indian forest land or rangeland are limited to 20 years and can be renewed for an additional 10 years. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can conduct demonstration projects allowing Indian tribes to manage programs under the Tribal Forest Protection Act through contracts under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 7. TRIBAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS. Any activity conducted or resources harvested under approved tribal resource management plans shall be considered sustainable for Federal standards. SEC. 8. LEASES OF RESTRICTED LANDS FOR THE NAVAJO NATION. SEC. 8. LEASES OF RESTRICTED LANDS FOR THE NAVAJO NATION. Subsection (e)(1) of the Long-Term Leasing Act is amended to allow leases for mineral resources for 25 years with an option to renew for an additional 25 years. SEC. 9. NONAPPLICABILITY OF CERTAIN RULES. Rules by the Department of the Interior on hydraulic fracturing for oil or gas won't affect Indian trust lands without beneficiary consent.
